children.name: OpciónA
children.value: He replies immediately with a long email defending his position and pointing out his colleague’s mistake.

children.name: OpciónB
children.value: He calmly reviews the previous emails to identify where the confusion started and whether there was a misinterpretation.

children.name: OpciónC
children.value: He sends a short email suggesting a meeting or call to clarify the situation directly.

children.name: OpciónD
children.value: He decides to ignore the email and continue with his work, thinking it will “resolve itself later.”

children.name: Situación
children.value: Emilio receives an email from a colleague in another department mentioning a change in the deliverable. However, the message is ambiguous, and it is not clear whether the change applies to his part of the project or to something else. By replying too quickly without verifying, a misunderstanding arises.

children.name: OpciónA
children.value: Assumes that the last oral instruction is valid, even though there is no written record.

children.name: OpciónB
children.value: Reviews the entire chat and saves screenshots, but does not ask anything to avoid interrupting.

children.name: OpciónC
children.value: Sends a confirmation email to all involved, summarizing what he understood and asking for validation.

children.name: OpciónD
children.value: Downloads any file shared in the meeting, even if he is not sure it is the latest version.

children.name: Situación
children.value: In a virtual meeting, Emilio receives many mixed instructions in the chat and in the video call. At the end, he is not sure which is the official version of the document he should work on.

children.name: OpciónA
children.value: Spreads the rumor in the internal chat so everyone knows.

children.name: OpciónB
children.value: Keeps silent, but starts working less because he believes it’s no longer worth it.

children.name: OpciónC
children.value: Checks the official announcements directly on the company’s intranet or bulletins.

children.name: OpciónD
children.value: Asks a trusted coworker if they know “the truth” without looking at formal sources.

children.name: Situación
children.value: Emilio overhears two coworkers saying that “the department head will be replaced and the project will soon be canceled.” There is no official communication about it.

children.name: OpciónA
children.value: Emilio chooses the file that seems to have the best name without verifying the origin or validity of the information. He gives the presentation, but the results are incorrect.

children.name: OpciónB
children.value: He asks a trusted colleague which file to use. The colleague recommends one, but on the day of the presentation it turns out it was also the wrong one because no one had validated its origin.

children.name: OpciónC
children.value: He reviews each file, compares their content with previous documents and metadata (dates, authors, versions) to identify which are relevant and reliable.

children.name: OpciónD
children.value: He informs his manager that the database is disorganized, proposes a preliminary classification (renaming files, creating folders, annotating sources), and then selects the most reliable data for the project.

children.name: Situación
children.value: Emilio has been assigned a new project. His manager tells him he must complete it using the information available. However, the “database” is actually a collection of several spreadsheets with strange names and no order.

children.name: OpciónA
children.value: Emilio attends the 3 meetings without dedicating time to documenting, and asks the new team member to take notes of all the information he explains.

children.name: OpciónB
children.value: Emilio documents the most important parts of the project (methodology, key decisions, risks) and uses the meetings to resolve doubts and provide additional context.

children.name: OpciónC
children.value: Emilio requests more time to thoroughly document before moving on to the new project, even though this delays meetings and the start of the next project.

children.name: OpciónD
children.value: Emilio decides the meetings are unnecessary and does not document anything else, trusting that if doubts arise, they will look for him once he is already on the new project.

children.name: Situación
children.value: Emilio has to attend 3 meetings during the week about the progress of his project, since he will be assigned to a new one next week. Having previously experienced how complicated it is to receive a project without documentation, he wants to record as much of the process as possible, but he doesn’t have enough time.

children.name: OpciónA
children.value: Emilio saves all the information on his personal computer and then sends it by email to the new team member.

children.name: OpciónB
children.value: Emilio uploads the most relevant files to the team’s Google Drive, creates an organized folder, and writes a basic index to make navigation easier.

children.name: OpciónC
children.value: Emilio asks IT or an experienced colleague for support in structuring the files in the internal Wiki, although this takes more time than planned.

children.name: OpciónD
children.value: Emilio uploads all the files as they are, with disorganized and duplicated names, thinking that “the new person will know how to arrange them as needed.”

children.name: Situación
children.value: Emilio has been working on a project for 4 months. Before being transferred to a new team, he must ensure that all information and progress are available to the rest of the department.

children.name: OpciónA
children.value: Do it without hesitation, plugging the USB into the boss’s computer. There was a virus, and he got scolded.

children.name: OpciónB
children.value: Refuse to do it, convincing the boss that it’s not possible because it’s a cybersecurity risk.

children.name: OpciónC
children.value: Emilio tries to persuade his boss to use an alternative method, such as Google Drive or a music streaming app.

children.name: OpciónD
children.value: Follow his boss’s request but run an emergency scan first. He detects the virus and prevents the infection.

children.name: Situación
children.value: Emilio’s boss asked him to transfer music from a personal USB drive to the company computer.

children.name: OpciónA
children.value: Emilio enters fake credentials in the email link “to trick the attacker.”

children.name: OpciónB
children.value: Emilio forwards the email to his coworkers as a joke, without warning that it’s phishing.

children.name: OpciónC
children.value: Emilio replies directly to the sender, questioning their attempt.

children.name: OpciónD
children.value: Emilio ignores the email, marks it as phishing, and reports it to the IT/cybersecurity team.

children.name: Situación
children.value: Emilio receives a suspicious email in his inbox that appears to be from a supplier, but he notices inconsistencies in the writing and the sender’s address. Although he is sure it’s a phishing attempt, he feels curious about “playing” with the email.

children.name: OpciónA
children.value: He sends the project files to his personal email to continue at home.

children.name: OpciónB
children.value: He ignores the pending tasks and decides to resume them in the morning at the office.

children.name: OpciónC
children.value: He advances as much as possible during work hours and leaves the rest for the next day.

children.name: OpciónD
children.value: He posts on social media that his job is “exploitative” and that he can’t leave because of outstanding tasks.

children.name: Situación
children.value: Emilio couldn’t finish a project at the office and thinks he can continue from home. However, the company hasn’t assigned him a laptop or authorized him to work from personal devices. Even so, he looks for a way to proceed.

children.name: OpciónA
children.value: Start talking about that thread with all your coworkers to see if they have any idea or information about the rumor.

children.name: OpciónB
children.value: Stay quiet and do nothing about it. It’s surely just lies...

children.name: OpciónC
children.value: Search online or check the company’s official posts to confirm this information.

children.name: OpciónD
children.value: Feel afraid and start looking for a Plan B in case it’s true.

children.name: Situación
children.value: Emilio’s friend told him she read in a social media thread that a lot of people in the company are going to be laid off.

children.name: OpciónA
children.value: Wait for official documentation to be released, even if this delays the entire project.

children.name: OpciónB
children.value: Follow his boss’s instructions and use the language model without verifying its answers, trusting blindly.

children.name: OpciónC
children.value: Tell his boss that using an LLM is impractical and reject its use without exploring alternatives.

children.name: OpciónD
children.value: Research the little documentation available, cross-check information with the LLM, and also test the tool to validate what works and what doesn’t.

children.name: Situación
children.value: Emilio, for the project he is working on, needs to use a new technology that was just released, so the available documentation is very limited. His boss urges him to use a language model as an interactive guide.

children.name: OpciónA
children.value: Use only the available data, even though he knows the analysis will be incomplete.

children.name: OpciónB
children.value: Ask his colleagues if there is a backup of the data or an alternative source within the system.

children.name: OpciónC
children.value: Inform his boss that the data is damaged and that he needs guidance on how to proceed before delivering results.

children.name: OpciónD
children.value: Invent data to complete the report and avoid delays.

children.name: Situación
children.value: Emilio needs to evaluate a dataset for the project he is working on, but part of the information is corrupted, making it impossible to use in its entirety.

children.name: OpciónA
children.value: Choose the report with the better numbers, thinking it will make his team look good.

children.name: OpciónB
children.value: Review the source of each report, evaluate which has the most reliable information, and document the differences.

children.name: OpciónC
children.value: Ask a more experienced colleague how these types of inconsistencies are usually handled.

children.name: OpciónD
children.value: Present both reports as they are, without analysis, to “avoid taking risks.”

children.name: Situación
children.value: Emilio receives two performance reports from the department, but both show different figures for the same indicator. His boss asks him for a strategic analysis for the upcoming meeting.

children.name: OpciónA
children.value: Deliver the preliminary report without warning that the information is unverified.

children.name: OpciónB
children.value: Deliver the preliminary report, but include notes clarifying the limitations and risks of the data.

children.name: OpciónC
children.value: Deliver a short summary with what he has so far and propose a plan to gather and validate the rest of the information in the short term.

children.name: OpciónD
children.value: Consult with other colleagues to see if anyone has complementary information and present a joint version.

children.name: Situación
children.value: The boss wants an immediate report to make a strategic decision, but Emilio only has preliminary data without full context.

children.name: OpciónA
children.value: Uses the first tool he knows (Excel) without checking if it complies with company policies.

children.name: OpciónB
children.value: Investigates which tool has been used in similar projects and applies that one.

children.name: OpciónC
children.value: Consults with trusted colleagues about which option is more appropriate, even if the boss is upset.

children.name: OpciónD
children.value: Decides to do nothing until the boss calms down, delaying the task.

children.name: Situación
children.value: Emilio is tasked with collecting the responses from a company form. He is unsure which digital tool to use (Google Forms, Excel, or the corporate platform). However, his boss is upset about an unrelated matter, and Emilio doesn’t know whether to consult him or not.

children.name: OpciónA
children.value: Does not ask questions and continues working with the incomplete information, producing a poor-quality output.

children.name: OpciónB
children.value: Reviews internal digital sources (corporate wiki, previous meeting minutes, intranet) to complement the information.

children.name: OpciónC
children.value: Asks colleagues or the boss directly to clarify doubts, prioritizing accuracy over image.

children.name: OpciónD
children.value: Copies old documents from similar projects without validating their relevance.

children.name: Situación
children.value: Emilio thinks the project documentation is incomplete and unclear. Out of fear of “looking bad,” he prefers not to ask questions and works almost blindly.

children.name: OpciónA
children.value: Applies to the vacancy immediately without reading the full requirements or verifying if the information is official.

children.name: OpciónB
children.value: Verifies with the Human Resources department that the vacancy is legitimate and up-to-date before applying.

children.name: OpciónC
children.value: Downloads the vacancy information, saves it in his personal folder, and compares it with his career plan before deciding.

children.name: OpciónD
children.value: Shares the vacancy in external chats and social networks without confirming whether it is internal and confidential.

children.name: Situación
children.value: Emilio sees a new job vacancy posted only on the company’s internal portal. He reviews it and thinks it matches his interests and goals.

content.text: [b]a)[/b] Responde de inmediato con un correo largo defendiendo su postura y señalando el error del compañero.

Emilio recibe un correo de un compañero de otro departamento en el que se menciona un cambio en el entregable. Sin embargo, el mensaje es ambiguo y no queda claro si el cambio aplica a su parte del proyecto o a otra. Al responder rápidamente sin verificar, surge una discusión por malentendido.
[b]b)[/b] Revisa con calma los correos anteriores para identificar dónde surgió la confusión y si hubo una mala interpretación.
[b]c)[/b] Envía un correo breve proponiendo una reunión o llamada para aclarar la situación directamente.
[b]d)[/b] Decide ignorar el correo y continuar con su trabajo, pensando que “ya se resolverá solo”.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: SmoothCamera
eventsFunctionsExtensions.previewIconUrl: https://resources.gdevelop-app.com/assets/Icons/Line Hero Pack/Master/SVG/Computers and Hardware/Computers and Hardware_camcoder_gopro_go_pro_camera.svg
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Smoothly scroll to follow an object.
description: The camera follows an object according to:
- a frame rate independent catch-up speed to make the scrolling from smooth to strong
- a maximum speed to do linear following ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://platformer-with-tilemap)) or slow down the camera when teleporting the object
- a follow-free zone to avoid scrolling on small movements
- an offset to see further in one direction
- an extra delay and catch-up speed to give an impression of speed (useful for dash)
- position forecasting and delay to simulate a cameraman response time
A platformer dedicated behavior allows to switch of settings when the character is in air or on the floor. This can be used to stabilize the camera when jumping.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Smoothly scroll to follow an object.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: SmoothCamera

events.comment: Update private properties through setters to check their values and initialize state.

eventsFunctions.description: Move the camera closer to the object. This action must be called after the object has moved for the frame.
eventsFunctions.name: MoveCameraCloser

events.comment: The camera following is called with an action, the call from doStepPreEvents must be disabled to avoid to do it twice.

eventsFunctions.description: Move the camera closer to the object.
eventsFunctions.name: DoMoveCameraCloser

events.comment:
Delaying and forecasting can be used at the same time.
Forecasting only use the positions that are older than the one used for delaying.
The behavior uses a position history that is split in 2 arrays:
- one for delaying the position (from TimeFromStart to TimeFromStart - CamearDelay)
- one for forecasting the position (from TimeFromStart - CamearDelay to TimeFromStart - CamearDelay - ForecastHistoryDuration

At each frame, the camera must catchup the target by a given ratio (speed)
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - 1) - targetX) * speed

The frame rate must not impact on the catch-up speed, we don't want a speed in ratio per frame but a speed ratio per second, like this:
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - 1s) - targetX) * speed

Ok, but we still need to process each frame, we can use a exponent for this:
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - timeDelta) - targetX) * speed^timeDelta
cameraX(t) = targetX + (cameraX(t - timeDelta) - targetX) * exp(timeDelta * ln(speed))

pow is probably more efficient than precalculated log if the speed is changed continuously but this might be rare enough.

eventsFunctions.description: Delay the camera according to a maximum speed and catch up the delay.
eventsFunctions.name: WaitAndCatchUp
eventsFunctions.sentence: Delay the camera of _PARAM0_ during: _PARAM2_ seconds according to the maximum speed _PARAM3_;_PARAM4_ seconds and catch up in _PARAM5_ seconds

events.comment: Maybe the catch-up show be done in constant pixel speed instead of constant time speed.

eventsFunctions.description: Update delayed position and delayed history. This is called in doStepPreEvents.
eventsFunctions.name: UpdateDelayedPosition
eventsFunctions.sentence: Update delayed position and delayed history of _PARAM0_

events.comment: Add the previous position to have enough (2) positions to evaluate the extra delay for waiting mode.
Use the object center when no delay is asked.
Remove history entries that are too old to be useful for delaying and pass it to the history for forecasting.
Don't move the camera if there is not enough history.

Add the extra delay that could be needed to respect the speed limit in waiting mode.

speedRatio = min(speedMaxX / historySpeedX, speedMaxY / historySpeedY)
delay += min(0, timeDelta * (1 - speedRatio))
The time with delay is now between the first 2 indexes

eventsFunctions.name: IsWaiting

eventsFunctions.description: Add a position to the history for forecasting. This is called 2 times in UpadteDelayedPosition.
eventsFunctions.name: AddForecastHistoryPosition
eventsFunctions.sentence: Add the time:_PARAM2_ and position: _PARAM3_; _PARAM4_ to the forecast history of _PARAM0_

events.comment:
Remove history entries that are too old to be useful.
Keep at least 2 positions because no forecast can be done with less positions.

eventsFunctions.description: Update forecasted position. This is called in doStepPreEvents.
eventsFunctions.name: UpdateForecastedPosition

events.comment:
Simple linear regression
y = A * x + B

A = Covariance / VarianceX
B = MeanY - A * MeanX

Note than we could use only one position every N positions to reduce the process time,
but if we really need efficient process JavaScript and circular queues are a must.

VarianceX = sum((X[i] - MeanX)²)
VarianceY = sum((Y[i] - MeanY)²)
Covariance = sum((X[i] - MeanX) * (Y[i] - MeanY))

y = A * x + B

A = Covariance / VarianceX
B = MeanY - A * MeanX
Axis permutation to avoid a ratio between 2 numbers near 0.
Permute back axis

eventsFunctions.description: Project history ends position to have the vector on the line from linear regression. This function is only called by UpdateForecastedPosition.
eventsFunctions.name: ProjectHistoryEnds
eventsFunctions.sentence: Project history oldest: _PARAM2_;_PARAM3_ and newest position: _PARAM4_;_PARAM5_ of _PARAM0_

events.comment:
Perpendicular line:
pA = -1/a; 
pB = -pA * x + y

Intersection:
/ ProjectedY = a * ProjectedX + b
\ ProjectedY = pA * ProjectedX + b

Solution that is cleaned out from indeterminism (like 0 / 0 or infinity / infinity):
ProjectedX= (x + (y - b) * a) / (a² + 1)
ProjectedY = y + (x * a - y + b) / (a² + 1)

eventsFunctions.description: Return the ratio between forecast time and the duration of the history. This function is only called by UpdateForecastedPosition.
eventsFunctions.name: ForecastTimeRatio

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: PanelSpriteButton
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: A button that can be customized.
description: A button that can be used for menus and most labelled buttons of a game. The button can be customized with a background for each state and a label. It handles user interactions and a simple condition can be used to check if it is clicked.
There are ready-to-use buttons in the asset-store [menu buttons pack](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?initial-dialog=asset-store&asset-pack=menu-buttons-menu-buttons).

changelog.breaking: - Buttons now use "variants", allowing easy swapping of their visual aspect. You will have to make some adjustments to existing buttons in your project. Follow this [migration documentation](https://wiki.gdevelop.io/gdevelop5/objects/custom-objects-prefab-template/migrate-to-variants/) to do these changes.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: The finite state machine used internally by the button object.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: ButtonFSM

events.comment: The "Validated" state only last one frame.
Make sure the cursor position is only checked once per frame.
Touches are always pressed, so ShouldCheckHovering doesn't matter.

Show the right background accordingly to the new state.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @Bouh, @arthuro555
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: CursorType
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Provides an action to change the type of the cursor, and a behavior to change the cursor when an object is hovered.
description: Provides an action to change the type of the cursor, and a behavior to change the cursor when an object is hovered.
Find the list of cursors here: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/cursor

eventsFunctions.description: Change the type of the cursor.
eventsFunctions.name: ChangeCursorType

events.comment:
Set as variable instead of directly setting as a CursorHover behavior can override it.
By using a variable, we ensure to be able to change it back to that "default" after the override is over.

eventsFunctions.description: Do change the type of the cursor.
eventsFunctions.name: DoChangeCursorType

events.comment: Reset ordering as the object with highest Z-Order might not exist anymore or be not be hovered anymore.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Change the cursor appearence when the object is hovered (on Windows, macOS or Linux).
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: CursorHover

events.comment: Check the z Order to ensure the cursor shown is the one from the foremost object

propertyDescriptors.label: The cursor type
propertyDescriptors.description: See https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/cursor for a list of possible cursors.
propertyDescriptors.name: CursorType

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: ButtonStates
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Use any object as a button and change appearance according to user interactions.
description: Use the "Button states" behavior to track user interactions with an object, including:
- Hovered
- Pressed
- Clicked
- Idle
Add additional behaviors to make juicy buttons with animated responses to user input:
- Size
- Color
- Animation
- Object effects

events.comment: The "Validated" state only last one frame.
Make sure the cursor position is only checked once per frame.
Touches are always pressed, so ShouldCheckHovering doesn't matter.

eventsFunctions.description: Reset the state of the button.
eventsFunctions.name: ResetState

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the button is not used.
eventsFunctions.name: IsIdle

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the button was just clicked.
eventsFunctions.name: IsClicked

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the cursor is hovered over the button.
eventsFunctions.name: IsHovered

eventsFunctions.name: IsFocused

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the button is currently being pressed outside with mouse or touch.
eventsFunctions.name: IsPressedOutside

eventsFunctions.description: the touch id that is using the button or 0 if none.
eventsFunctions.name: TouchId

eventsFunctions.name: PlayTween
eventsFunctions.sentence: Tween the effect property of object _PARAM0_ over _PARAM2_ seconds with _PARAM3_ easing

eventsFunctions.description: the effect name of the object.
